edge: Glass watches as American soldiers burn down a Native American village in the Great Plains.
Glass guides Captain Andrew Henry's trappers through the territory of the present-day Dakotas.
Glass guides Captain Andrew Henry's trappers during the Arikara War in late 1823.
The Arikara war party is seeking to recover its chief's abducted daughter, Powaqa.
Glass is mauled and left near death by a female grizzly bear that is guarding her cubs.
Fearing another Arikara attack, John Fitzgerald argues that the group must mercy-kill Glass and keep moving.
Henry agrees, but he is unable to pull the trigger.
The only volunteers who stay with Glass and bury him after he dies are Hawk, Jim Bridger, and Fitzgerald.
When the only volunteers leave, Fitzgerald attempts to smother Glass but is stopped when Glass's son Hawk intervenes.
After the others leave, Fitzgerald attempts to smother Glass but is stopped when Glass's son Hawk intervenes. Fitzgerald stabs Hawk to death as Glass watches helplessly.
Glass half-buried alive in a makeshift grave while Hawk holds Fitzgerald at gunpoint and shouts for Bridger, who is away gathering water.
Bridger forces Fitzgerald to admit that there are no pursuing Arikara. Fitzgerald falsely reports to Henry that Hawk vanished and Glass died.
Glass eludes the pursuing Arikara by jumping into river rapids.
The men share a conversation about revenge and its relation to faith.
